=====
Characteristics of the Subfamily Oxaeinae, of the Andrenidae:
- Stigma essentially absent; marginal cell over seven times as long as broad and only half as wide as widest submarginal cell (Fig. 60-2a); mentum absent or fused to ﬂat lorum; proboscidial lobe absent; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment as long as scape (Western Hemisphere)
=====
Characteristics of the Subfamily Andreninae, of the Andrenidae:
- Stigma present; marginal cell shorter and broader, about as wide as widest submarginal cell; mentum and lorum both present, forming proboscidial lobe; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than scape
- Apex of marginal cell pointed or narrowly rounded on or near wing margin (Fig. 51-2) (facial fovea not or weakly evident in male, in female, when present, slightly depressed, covered with short hairs; gonobase of male distinct and large, reduced to narrow ring or almost absent in Megandrena)
=====
Characteristics of the Subfamily Alocandreninae, of the Andrenidae:
- Stigma present; marginal cell shorter and broader, about as wide as widest submarginal cell; mentum and lorum both present, forming proboscidial lobe; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than scape
- Apex of marginal cell truncate, sometimes obliquely so, cell thus pointed well away from wing margin (Figs. 501f, 53-1)
- Facial fovea of both sexes a distinct deep pocket with short hairs (Fig. 50-1a, b); gonobase of male distinct and large (Fig. 50-1c-e) (Peru)
=====
Characteristics of the Subfamily Panurginae, of the Andrenidae:
- Stigma present; marginal cell shorter and broader, about as wide as widest submarginal cell; mentum and lorum both present, forming proboscidial lobe; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than scape
- Apex of marginal cell truncate, sometimes obliquely so, cell thus pointed well away from wing margin (Figs. 501f, 53-1)
- Facial fovea hairless and shining, often absent in males, rarely also in females (Melitturga); gonobase of male absent or nearly so
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Ancylandrena of the Andreninae (Females):
- Facial fovea depressed, velvety (Fig. 51-1a)
- Hairs of hind trochanter rather dense, short, the longer ones simple, not much curved; anterior surface of T1 broadly concave, much longer than dorsal surface of T1 (Fig. 51-1c, d) (southwestern North America)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Andrena of the Andreninae (Females):
- Facial fovea depressed, velvety (Fig. 51-1a)
- Some hairs of hind trochanter long, curved distad, plumose, forming a ﬂoccus (Fig. 51-1b) closing basal end of femoral corbicula; anterior surface of T1 with smaller concavity or groove, surface shorter than to slightly longer than dorsal surface of T1 (Fig. 51-1e, f)
- Hind basitarsus more than half as long as hind tibia; stigma often broader than prestigma (measured to wing margin), margins usually converging basad from vein r (Fig. 51-2a, b)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Megandrena of the Andreninae (Males):
- Gonobase a narrow ring or essentially absent (Fig. 51-7a, b); mandible simple or with weak preapical shoulder on upper margin (southwestern USA)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Andrena of the Andreninae (Males):
- Gonobase with broad dorsal surface; mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin (except in Euherbstia from Chile)
- Anterior surface of T1 largely convex, the concavity a median, longitudinal groove or depression, this surface shorter than to slightly longer than distance from its upper end to apex of T1; hind basitarsus ﬁve or more times as long as wide
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Euherbstia of the Andreninae (Males):
- Gonobase with broad dorsal surface; mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin (except in Euherbstia from Chile)
- Anterior surface of T1 largely ﬂat (in Euherbstia) or concave, the concavity a median, longitudinal line or groove, this surface usually longer than distance from its upper end to apex of T1; hind basitarsus less than ﬁve times as long as wide
- Mandible simple; inner subantennal suture converging below toward outer suture, so that subantennal area has only short margin on epistomal suture (Chile)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Orphana of the Andreninae (Males):
- Gonobase with broad dorsal surface; mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin (except in Euherbstia from Chile)
- Anterior surface of T1 largely ﬂat (in Euherbstia) or concave, the concavity a median, longitudinal line or groove, this surface usually longer than distance from its upper end to apex of T1; hind basitarsus less than ﬁve times as long as wide
- Mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin; inner subantennal suture not converging strongly below toward outer suture
- S7 a broad plate with large median apical process (anterolateral processes partly hairy, not comparable to anterolateral apodemes, Fig. 51-6h); epistomal suture separated from antennal socket by much less than diameter of socket (Chile)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Ancylandrena of the Andreninae (Males):
- Gonobase with broad dorsal surface; mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin (except in Euherbstia from Chile)
- Anterior surface of T1 largely ﬂat (in Euherbstia) or concave, the concavity a median, longitudinal line or groove, this surface usually longer than distance from its upper end to apex of T1; hind basitarsus less than ﬁve times as long as wide
- Mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin; inner subantennal suture not converging strongly below toward outer suture
- S7 with a relatively small body, large anterolateral apodemes, and two small apical lobes (Fig. 51-3d); epistomal suture separated from antennal socket by about diameter of socket (Fig. 51-3e) (southwestern North America)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle coarsely sculptured
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aporandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Thoracic dorsum with hairs short, forming a dense mat
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Charitandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Thoracic dorsum with normal, long, plumose hairs not at all forming a mat obscuring surface
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Propodeum outside of triangle with punctures moderately roughening surface; dorsal femoral hairs often with abundant short, S-shaped branches bent away from rachis, appearing highly plumose; galeal blade generally narrow, its outer margin in apical half usually straight
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Malar area extremely short, linear, its length onesixth to one-tenth of its width; dorsolateral angle of pronotum weak; basal area of labrum simple, as long as broad or longer, strap-shaped or U-shaped with sides diverging slightly basad; propodeal triangle roughened at least mediobasally
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oligandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Facial quadrangle broader than long; propodeal corbicula poorly formed, lacking long internal hairs, dorsal hairs extremely short, not ﬂexed down over corbicular area (terga without pale apical fasciae)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Callandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Scopal hairs largely plumose
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Iomelissa) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Labial palpus elongate, but ﬁrst two segments not unusually long nor much ﬂattened; maxillary palpus elongate, more than half as long as galeal blade; basal area of labrum distinctly raised above general level of surface
- Maxillary palpus with second segment at least 1.5 times as long as ﬁrst; stipes distinctly narrowed medially and tapering apically, the apical third thus less than half as broad as basal third, with weak, plumose hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Erandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Labial palpus elongate, but ﬁrst two segments not unusually long nor much ﬂattened; maxillary palpus elongate, more than half as long as galeal blade; basal area of labrum distinctly raised above general level of surface
- Maxillary palpus with second segment about as long as ﬁrst; stipes linear, tapering from base to apex, with abundant, long, spinelike hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scrapteropsis) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- T2-T4 with depressed marginal zones less than half length of exposed part of each tergum medially
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- T2-T4 with depressed marginal zones half or more length of exposed part of each tergum medially
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Tylandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Pronotum laterally with deeply impressed groove cutting diagonally up and forward from pronotal spiracle to near midline anteriorly, this groove crossing and strongly depressing ridge extending down from dorsolateral angle; T2-T4 without apical pale fasciae or these weak and broadly interrupted; genal area broader than eye in side view; ocelloccipital distance about one and one-half to two and one-half ocellar diameters
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Diandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Integument often metallic blue or blue-green; propodeum outside of triangle roughened by punctures
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Parandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely tessellate; propodeal corbicula complete anteriorly, with few or no internal hairs; integument black or in part red, not metallic
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hesperandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Propodeum with lateral surface completely set off from dorsal and posterior surfaces by a carina, proﬁle declivous from base to apex; clypeus short
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Celetandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Subgenal coronet absent; vestiture largely black or dark brown (Mexico)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Scopal hairs entirely or mostly dark brown to black; pronotal dorsolateral ridge close to pronotal lobe; ﬁrst recurrent vein usually meeting second submarginal cell near middle of cell
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Archiandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal corbicula complete anteriorly, with few or no internal hairs; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment scarcely, if any, longer than second segment
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Scopal hairs entirely or mostly dark brown to black; pronotal dorsolateral ridge close to pronotal lobe; ﬁrst recurrent vein usually meeting second submarginal cell near middle of cell
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Belandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Labial palpal segments 2 and 3 each with next segment attached subapically, the third segment attached to second near middle of second segment; integument bright metallic blue-black; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell about two-thirds of cell length from base
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scoliandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Galeal blade with abundant short, hooked hairs; body usually ll mm long or more (integument usually metallic blue or black)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Derandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Pronotum with weak dorsolateral angle, the dorsoventral ridge absent or extremely weak; face below ocelli tessellate, without distinct longitudinal rugulae or punctures
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oxyandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Facial fovea extremely elongate, almost reaching vertex above, occupying most of paraocular space below; ocelloccipital distance half an ocellar diameter or less; terga impunctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Geissandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Hypostomal carina with longitudinal part longer than lateral part, lamellate, as high as two-thirds length of last labial palpal segment (clypeus with free apical margin elongate, moderately upturned; T2-T4 with pale apical fasciae interrupted medially)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dactylandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Malar area at least half as long as broad; propodeal corbicula incomplete, male-like; vestiture black
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Conandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Malar area about half as long as broad; pleural hairs pale ochraceous to white
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Middle basitarsus expanded medially (T2-T4 and usually T1 with complete apical pale fasciae of hairs with close-set, short barbs, giving them a dull appearance; basal area of labrum strongly bidentate and reﬂexed)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Larandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Median third of clypeus impunctate, shiny; tibial scopal hairs weakly plumose throughout; scutellum shiny, unshagreened at least medially
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xiphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- First ﬂagellar segment only slightly longer than second, about as long as third segment; propodeal triangle with distinct longitudinal rugulae ending posteriorly in irregularly reticulate rugulae (propodeal corbicula incomplete anteriorly, with abundant internal hairs)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhaphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Propodeal triangle with coarse longitudinal rugulae; metasomal terga distinctly punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nemandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Scutum between parapsidal lines with numerous, extremely ﬁne, longitudinal rugulae
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Gonandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Genal area often with strong posterior carina; scutellum shiny, unshagreened; propodeal triangle with rather coarse irregular sculpturing; clypeus with apical margin usually broad, distinctly reﬂexed or turned upward
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Malar area extremely short, linear, its length onesixth to one-tenth of its width; dorsolateral angle of pronotum weak; basal area of labrum simple, as long as broad or longer, strap-shaped or U-shaped with sides diverging slightly basad; propodeal triangle roughened at least mediobasally
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Onagrandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Vestiture entirely black or thoracic dorsum with reddish-brown hairs; propodeal triangle relatively coarsely and irregularly scuptured, forming small areolae; tibial scopal hairs long, simple, sparse
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dactylandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Malar area at least half as long as broad; propodeal corbicula incomplete, male-like; vestiture black
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Metasomal terga usually with weak, pale apical fasciae, weakly if at all punctate; pronotal dorsoventral ridge roughened below oblique groove; propodeal corbicula complete anteriorly
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Metasomal terga usually with weak, pale apical fasciae, weakly if at all punctate; pronotal dorsoventral ridge roughened below oblique groove; propodeal corbicula complete anteriorly
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
- Length 8-9 mm; stigma large, usually separated from vein r by two or three vein widths; pronotal dorsolateral angle distinct, dorsoventral ridge indistinct
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anchandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Basal area of labrum entire, short, three or more times as broad as long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Belandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Labial palpal segments 2 and 3 each with next segment attached subapically, the third segment attached to second near middle of second segment; integument bright metallic blue-black; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell about two-thirds of cell length from base
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Metasomal terga usually with weak, pale apical fasciae, weakly if at all punctate; pronotal dorsoventral ridge roughened below oblique groove; propodeal corbicula complete anteriorly
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Metasomal T2-T4 with distinct, pale apical fasciae often interrupted medially, the terga distinctly punctate; pronotal dorsoventral ridge usually sharp, subcarinate, or ifrounded below, then propodeal corbicula incomplete anteriorly
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Diandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Integument often metallic blue or blue-green; propodeum outside of triangle roughened by punctures
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pelicandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Integument not metallic; propodeum outside of triangle with punctures sparse, not roughening surface
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nemandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Scutum between parapsidal lines with numerous, extremely ﬁne, longitudinal rugulae
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dasyandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Mandible tridentate; subgenal coronet composed of several rows (5-8) of short, thick hairs forming a dense brush
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hesperandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Propodeum with lateral surface completely set off from dorsal and posterior surfaces by a carina, proﬁle declivous from base to apex; clypeus short
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Ocelloccipital distance about one-half ocellar diameter; integument usually slightly metallic blue-green; hind tibia cuneate with relatively short hairs; clypeal hairs plumose, all erect and only slightly curved near tips
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhacandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- T erga punctate; clypeus sparsely punctate, punctures mostly separated by two to three or more puncture widths; pronotum with oblique groove impressed
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Callandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Scopal hairs largely plumose
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Propodeal corbicula complete, bare internally
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Genyandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Subgenal coronet absent; ocelloccipital distance no more than half an ocellar width
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Propodeum outside of triangle with punctures moderately roughening surface; dorsal femoral hairs often with abundant short, S-shaped branches bent away from rachis, appearing highly plumose; galeal blade generally narrow, its outer margin in apical half usually straight
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cremnandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Vestiture of head, pleurae, and terga dark-brown; metasomal terga without pale apical fasciae; facial fovea narrow; facial quadrangle broader than long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Derandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Pronotum with weak dorsolateral angle, the dorsoventral ridge absent or extremely weak; face below ocelli tessellate, without distinct longitudinal rugulae or punctures
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Pronotum without both dorsolateral angle and ridge; face below ocelli rugulate and/or punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Genyandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Subgenal coronet absent; ocelloccipital distance no more than half an ocellar width
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scaphandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Vestiture entirely black; ocelloccipital distance one ocellar diameter or less
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Propodeal corbicula complete, bare internally
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scaphandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Vestiture entirely black; ocelloccipital distance one ocellar diameter or less
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Onagrandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Vestiture entirely black or thoracic dorsum with reddish-brown hairs; propodeal triangle relatively coarsely and irregularly scuptured, forming small areolae; tibial scopal hairs long, simple, sparse
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Belandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened
- Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved
- Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third
- Labial palpal segments 2 and 3 each with next segment attached subapically, the third segment attached to second near middle of second segment; integument bright metallic blue-black; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell about two-thirds of cell length from base
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhacandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- T erga punctate; clypeus sparsely punctate, punctures mostly separated by two to three or more puncture widths; pronotum with oblique groove impressed
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Propodeum outside of triangle with punctures moderately roughening surface; dorsal femoral hairs often with abundant short, S-shaped branches bent away from rachis, appearing highly plumose; galeal blade generally narrow, its outer margin in apical half usually straight
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhacandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- T erga punctate; clypeus sparsely punctate, punctures mostly separated by two to three or more puncture widths; pronotum with oblique groove impressed
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Psammandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Labrum below basal area with strong median crista, often lamellate, and with strong lateral crista and two shiny transverse sulci (metasomal terga tessellate, opaque)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Propodeum outside of triangle with punctures moderately roughening surface; dorsal femoral hairs often with abundant short, S-shaped branches bent away from rachis, appearing highly plumose; galeal blade generally narrow, its outer margin in apical half usually straight
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Thysandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Propodeum outside of triangle without punctures, smoothly tessellate or shagreened; dorsal femoral hairs with relatively short, stiff barbs or simple; galeal blade with outer apical margin gently convex, broad at base
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scaphandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Vestiture entirely black; ocelloccipital distance one ocellar diameter or less
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Vestiture in part or largely pale; or, if mostly black, then ocelloccipital distance one and one-half to two ocellar diameters
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pelicandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and often base of second ﬂagellar segment excavated below
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Diandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus metallic blue, often with violaceous reﬂections; basal area of labrum usually bidentate; propodeal triangle usually moderately coarsely sculptured
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Callandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Ocelloccipital distance usually one ocellar diameter or more, but if as short as half an ocellar diameter, then either integument not metallic or paraocular areas without pale maculae or both
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Onagrandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Maxillary palpus exceeding tip of galea by at least length of two apical segments
- First ﬂagellar segment usually at least as long as second, rarely slightly shorter, second segment usually shorter than third; labial palpus normal, second and third segments slender, not nearly as broad as long; integument black or with extremely faint metallic reﬂections
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Parandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Maxillary palpus exceeding tip of galea by at least length of two apical segments
- Clypeus and paraocular areas white to yellow; propodeum outside of triangle not roughened by coarse punctures
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dactylandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Malar space one-third to one-half as long as broad, or longer, but if as short as one-third as long as broad, then anterior trochanter with spinelike process on anterior surface near apex; clypeus yellow; facial quadrangle usually as broad as long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Genyandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- Clypeus yellow; propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured, shagreened or ﬁnely tessellate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xiphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- Clypeus black; propodeal triangle coarsely sculptured, irregularly rugulose
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oligandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- Facial quadrangle distinctly broader than long; metasomal terga without pale apical fasciae; pronotum with dorsolateral angle indistinct, displaced toward midline (dorsoventral pronotal ridge distinct)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Archiandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- Pygidial plate well developed, narrow, V-shaped; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually about two-thirds as long as second
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Belandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Galeal blade sharply pointed and spear-shaped, evenly tapering from base to apex, narrow
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Geissandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus with apical margin broad, turned forward; propodeal triangle ﬁnely areolate mediobasally (T2-T5 with distinct pale apical fasciae)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Genal area with posterior margin distinctly carinate; stigma large, ﬁrst submarginal crossvein ending on marginal cell within two or three vein widths of stigma; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment as long as or longer than second plus third
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Larandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Basal area of labrum trapezoidal, often with small but distinct median emargination; integument, except clypeus, black, nonmetallic
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Derandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Basal area of labrum entire, rounded, short (several times broader than long), or, if trapezoidal and slightly emarginate, then integument largely metallic blue
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anchandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Malar area distinct, six times as broad as long or longer; metasomal terga usually impunctate or indistinctly punctate; propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Basal area of labrum short, four times as broad as long, entire to weakly emarginate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Tylandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Pronotum with dorsoventral ridge extending down from dorsolateral angle interrupted by distinct, oblique, deeply impressed groove; T2-T4 usually without pale apical fasciae; clypeus short, not produced much beyond level of lower ends of compound eyes
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Gonandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Genal area with posterior margin distinctly carinate; clypeus with apical area long, distinctly turned forward; T2-T5 with more or less distinct pale apical fasciae
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- T2-T4 and often T5 with more or less distinct pale apical fasciae; ocelloccipital distance about one ocellar diameter, often less and rarely slightly more
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- T1 and usually T2 medially with abundant long, erect to suberect hairs; basal area of labrum usually bidentate; maxillary palpal segments not all elongate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Basal area of labrum short, four times as broad as long, entire to weakly emarginate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhaphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Basal area of labrum long, bidentate, usually reﬂexed
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- T1-T5 or T2-T5 with pale apical fasciae composed of long, blunt hairs with abundant, extremely short barbs, giving hairs an opaque appearance in strong light; basal area of labrum strongly bidentate and strongly reﬂexed, usually elevated well above margin of clypeus, its apical teeth turned under
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- T1 and usually T2 medially with abundant long, erect to suberect hairs; basal area of labrum usually bidentate; maxillary palpal segments not all elongate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- T1 and T2 without long, erect to suberect hairs, T1 bare or with short, sparse, erect hairs; basal area of labrum entire or only weakly emarginate apically; maxillary palpal segments all moderately elongate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scoliandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Basal area of labrum large, entire, subtriangular, about as long as broad; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment twice as long as second; integument dark metallic blue or blue-black
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Ocelloccipital distance half an ocellar diameter or less, rarely slightly more; integument dull metallic blue; clypeus and paraocular areas pale yellow
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Callandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Ocelloccipital distance usually one ocellar diameter or more, but if as short as half an ocellar diameter, then either integument not metallic or paraocular areas without pale maculae or both
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Propodeum with lateral sutures delimiting triangle slightly raised; clypeus impunctate or punctures obscured by dense regular tessellation or coarse shagreening; integument black, never metallic
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Propodeal triangle margined by acarinate lateral bounding sutures, mere lines or slight depressions; dorsal surface of propodeum often longer than scutellum
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Maxillary palpus exceeding tip of galea by at least length of two apical segments
- Inner hind tibial spur slightly broadened basally by a membranous ﬂange, often strongly curved, broader than outer spur; S6 bent downward and forward apicolaterally to form two reﬂexed blunt teeth; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell near or only slightly beyond middle of cell
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Maxillary palpus exceeding tip of galea by at least length of two apical segments
- Marginal zone of T2 one-third or more of median tergal length; third ﬂagellar segment usually two-thirds as wide as long or longer, antennae in repose usually reaching beyond scutellum; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell near middle of cell, rarely beyond
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scrapteropsis) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Maxillary palpus exceeding tip of galea by at least length of two apical segments
- Marginal zone of T2 less than one-third of median tergal length; third ﬂagellar segment distinctly more than two-thirds as wide as long, antennae in repose usually not reaching beyond middle of scutellum; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell two-thirds or more of length of cell from base
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Maxillary palpus exceeding tip of galea by at least length of two apical segments
- Clypeus ﬂattened mediobasally; metasomal terga distinctly punctate, surface and bottoms of punctures dulled by ﬁne tessellation; T2-T5 with pale apical fasciae, but these often interrupted medially
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scaphandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Clypeus usually white or cream-colored; T2-T4, but rarely T1, with apical pale fasciae; S2-S5 with subapical ﬁmbriae weak (short) or absent (if with weak sternal ﬁmbriae, then without fascia on T1); hind tibia broad, cuneate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- T2-T5 without pale apical fasciae, or,if present on some terga, then weak, and ocelloccipital distance at least one and one-half ocellar diameters, often more
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Onagrandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Maxillary palpus exceeding tip of galea by at least length of two apical segments
- First ﬂagellar segment usually at least as long as second, rarely slightly shorter, second segment usually shorter than third; labial palpus normal, second and third segments slender, not nearly as broad as long; integument black or with extremely faint metallic reﬂections
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scaphandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Clypeus usually white or cream-colored; T2-T4, but rarely T1, with apical pale fasciae; S2-S5 with subapical ﬁmbriae weak (short) or absent (if with weak sternal ﬁmbriae, then without fascia on T1); hind tibia broad, cuneate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dasyandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Sternal subapical ﬁmbriae exceptionally long; space between clypeus and antennal sockets less than one socket diameter (western USA)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Psammandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells two
- First and second ﬂagellar segments terete or ﬂattened and expanded laterally but not excavated below
- Clypeus yellow, white, or black; basal area of labrum bidentate or entire; propodeal triangle usually ﬁnely sculptured
- Maxillary palpus exceeding tip of galea by at least length of two apical segments
- Metasomal terga dull, opaque, tessellation obscuring punctures if present; S6 ﬂat apically
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scaphandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Clypeus usually white or cream-colored; T2-T4, but rarely T1, with apical pale fasciae; S2-S5 with subapical ﬁmbriae weak (short) or absent (if with weak sternal ﬁmbriae, then without fascia on T1); hind tibia broad, cuneate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhacandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Clypeus usually yellow; T1-T4 with apical pale fasciae; S2-S5 with well-formed pale subapical ﬁmbriae; hind tibia not broadened apically, not cuneate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Propodeum with lateral sutures delimiting triangle slightly raised; clypeus impunctate or punctures obscured by dense regular tessellation or coarse shagreening; integument black, never metallic
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Metasomal sterna lacking pale subapical ﬁmbriae; terga often without pale apical fasciae; propodeum outside of triangle distinctly punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Metasomal sterna lacking pale subapical ﬁmbriae; terga often without pale apical fasciae; propodeum outside of triangle distinctly punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dasyandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Sternal subapical ﬁmbriae exceptionally long; space between clypeus and antennal sockets less than one socket diameter (western USA)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oxyandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Galeal blade narrow, spear-shaped, outer margin of apical half straight; basal area of labrum simple
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Thysandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- Galeal blade broad basally, outer margin of apical half or less gently concave; basal area of labrum usually emarginate apically
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- T2-T4 and often T5 with more or less distinct pale apical fasciae; ocelloccipital distance about one ocellar diameter, often less and rarely slightly more
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986):
- Submarginal cells three
- T2-T5 without pale apical fasciae, or,if present on some terga, then weak, and ocelloccipital distance at least one and one-half ocellar diameters, often more
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Orandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Facial fovea broad in upper part, narrow and deeply channeled in lower part
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cryptandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Clypeus distinctly broader than long; basal area of labrum very broad and short, rectangular
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Avandrena)(in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Facial fovea short and rectangular, at most twice as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rufandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Facial fovea usually long and not rectangular; hind femur strong, its inner side ﬂattened and limited above by a more or less conspicuously developed linear carina
- Facial fovea short and drop-shaped; metasomal terga fairly strongly to strongly and densely punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Facial fovea usually long and not rectangular; hind femur strong, its inner side ﬂattened and limited above by a more or less conspicuously developed linear carina
- Facial fovea long, or, if drop-shaped, then metasomal terga with scattered deep punctures
- Inner side of hind femur with weak carina and sparse, long bristles; lateral area of labrum small; metasomal terga usually with scattered deep punctures
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Lepidandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Facial fovea usually long and not rectangular; hind femur strong, its inner side ﬂattened and limited above by a more or less conspicuously developed linear carina
- Facial fovea long, or, if drop-shaped, then metasomal terga with scattered deep punctures
- Inner side of hind femur with strong carina and dense, short bristles; lateral area of labrum about as large as median area; metasomal terga strongly and densely punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melanapis) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Pronotum with dorsolateral angle elevated, abruptly cut off laterally
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Propodeal corbicula only weakly rugose in posterior part; body black to red
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Agandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Propodeal corbicula with strongly developed rugae, mostly lengthwise; body brilliant metallic blue
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scitandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Mesepisternum and propodeum glossy, coarsely and deeply punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Suandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Propodeal triangle weakly rugosely areolate to posterior margin; inner side of hind femur conspicuously carinate; basal area of labrum small and usually triangular
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pallandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Propodeal triangle with middle area shagreened, covered with ﬁne rugae; inner side of hind femur not carinate; basal area of labrum of medium size, deeply notched
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Charitandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Glossa greatly elongated, at least six times as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ulandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Glossa of normal length, about three times as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubiandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Propodeum declivous from the metanotum; facial fovea short and drop-shaped (head large)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Avandrena)(in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Facial fovea short and rectangular, at most twice as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Brachyandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Facial fovea small, upper part drop-shaped, lower part greatly reduced and fading out
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Biareolina) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Submarginal cells two
=====

Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aenandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Mesepisternum behind attachment of foreleg conspicuously compressed and ﬂat to deeply grooved; hairs of thorax squamose to minutely branched
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena)(in part) and A. (Fumandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A.
