Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Propodeal triangle strongly rugose to rugosely areolated; clypeus not grooved; facial fovea long, usually broad, and occupying about one-third of paraocular area
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Graecandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Propodeal triangle near metanotum ﬁnely but conspicuously and evenly rugose; facial fovea moderately long, uniformly broad, and occupying about one-third of paraocular area
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aciandr ena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Facial fovea short, not extending below upper margin of antennal socket
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Distandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Facial fovea long, usually extending below upper margin of antennal socket
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Parandrenella) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Body under 10 mm long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hyperandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Body over 15 mm long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Didonia) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Glossa much more than four times as long as broad; clypeus more or less distinctly snout-shaped, convex, or basal area of labrum broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chrysandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Tibial scopa strongly plumose; glossa about four times as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Tibial scopa not to very brieﬂy plumose; glossa less than three times as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Surface of propodeal corbicula impunctate and bare, its margin entirely densely hairy; metanotum with dense, light tuft of hairs directed forward
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena)and A. (Troandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Clypeus ﬂattened and frequently more or less distinctly concave in middle; basal area of labrum short, as if strongly compressed in lengthwise direction; facial fovea occupying almost whole paraocular area
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Facial fovea occupying almost whole paraocular area; clypeus strongly punctate; propodeal triangle ﬁnely reticulate, shagreened to glossy
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nobandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Metasomal terga almost bare except for complete or interrupted hair bands; facial fovea fading away upward; clypeus elongate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melittoides) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Very large species (body length 16-18 mm) with broad maxilla
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scaphandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided
- Medium-sized to large species (less than 16 mm) with weakly developed maxilla
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Clypeus longer than broad, transversely convex; facial fovea long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poliandrena)(in part) and A. (T arsandrena)(in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Clypeus broader than long, ﬂattened; facial fovea short, not extending below level of antennal bases
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cryptandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Clypeus distinctly broader than long; basal area of labrum very broad and short, rectangular
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cordandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Clypeus as long as broad; basal area of labrum narrower.. 42 42(41). T erga uniformly densely punctate, apical marginal zones also punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Thysandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- T1 impunctate; metanotum with weak, forwarddirected tuft of dense hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) —. Basal area of labrum short-triangular A. (Larandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Clypeus transversely wrinkled; basal area of labrum narrow and elongated; pygidial plate with elevated area
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Facial fovea usually long and not rectangular; hind femur strong, its inner side ﬂattened and limited above by a more or less conspicuously developed linear carina
- Maxillary palpus surpassing galea by about last three segments; active in spring
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Facial fovea usually long and not rectangular; hind femur strong, its inner side ﬂattened and limited above by a more or less conspicuously developed linear carina
- Maxillary palpus surpassing galea by about one segment; autumnal
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Campylogaster) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Facial fovea usually long and not rectangular; hind femur strong, its inner side ﬂattened and limited above by a more or less conspicuously developed linear carina
- Basal area of labrum large, notched; body length over 11 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oreomelissa) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.:
- Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections
- Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts
- Facial fovea usually long and not rectangular; hind femur strong, its inner side ﬂattened and limited above by a more or less conspicuously developed linear carina
- Basal area of labrum small, although strongly elevated, entire; body length 11 mm or less
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rufandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 broadened, and on each side a long, bent spine distinctly visible among metasomal hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Mesepisternum strongly rugose in longitudinal direction, almost undulate-areolate; clypeus and adjacent parts of face yellow; S8 with broad, isolated transverse carina on outer side before apex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melanapis) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Clypeus dark; propodeum with distinct more or less horizontal and vertical surfaces
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Brachyandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Length under 7 mm; metasoma strongly and very densely punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Biareolina) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Length over 8 mm; metasoma strongly but usually only moderately densely punctate
- Submarginal cells two; antenna of male short, like that of a female
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Length over 8 mm; metasoma strongly but usually only moderately densely punctate
- Submarginal cells three; antenna of male longer than that of female
- Marginal zones of T2 to T4 occupying half of tergal lengths
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Agandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Length over 8 mm; metasoma strongly but usually only moderately densely punctate
- Submarginal cells three; antenna of male longer than that of female
- Marginal zones of T2 to T4 normal, narrow
- Metasoma shining like steel; body with whitish to yellowish-white hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Length over 8 mm; metasoma strongly but usually only moderately densely punctate
- Submarginal cells three; antenna of male longer than that of female
- Marginal zones of T2 to T4 normal, narrow
- Metasoma not so shiny; body dark-haired
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scitandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Metasoma ﬁnely and densely punctate; genitalia complex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Campylogaster) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Mesepisternum strongly and deeply punctate; head thick, with short clypeus; genitalia simple
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubiandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Propodeum entirely declivous; ocelloccipital distance almost as long as four midﬂagellar segments taken together
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena)(in part) and A. (Fumandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Propodeal triangle strongly to weakly rugose, usually areolate to posterior truncation of basal area (clypeus black)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Distandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- First ﬂagellar segment at least as long as second and third taken together; clypeus usually longitudinally grooved and weakly elongated, always black; genitalia simple with elongated gonostylus, which is uniformly broad to apex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aciandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Clypeus yellow or rarely black; gonostylus slightly angled, shovel-shaped
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Graecandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Clypeus black or exceptionally yellow; gonostylus not as above
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena)and A. (Troandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Broad central area of clypeus ﬂattened, anterior edge truncate, punctation not strong; basal area of labrum shortened and transversely wrinkled basally
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Charitandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Clypeus yellow; mesepisternum with strongly inclined punctures having weak, downwardly elongated, raised margins
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Didonia) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Clypeus black; mesepisternum with round punctures lacking distinctly raised margins
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cryptandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum strongly rugosely areolate; metasoma strongly punctate and glossy; clypeus usually ﬂat (clypeus broader than long)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- T1 shagreened, with craterlike punctures (edges of punctures raised on all sides), or, if terga glossy and strongly punctate, then propodeal triangle toward metanotum at most weakly rugose
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Suandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Propodeal triangle alveolarly areolate to posterior margin; mesepisternum not alveolar but punctures slightly sloped, with weakly raised margins (genitalia typically complex)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny to shagreened, without rugae; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell far beyond middle; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually very short, seldom longer than second
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cordandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Metasoma shining, strongly and densely punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aenandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Clypeus and thorax shining, densely and strongly punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Thysandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Clypeus and thorax dull, sparsely and moderately ﬁnely punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Smaller species, less than 10 mm long; posterior metasomal terga usually with weakly developed, narrow bands
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Clypeus strongly convex, usually densely but shallowly punctate; metasoma usually ﬁnely and sparsely punctate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually only a little longer than second
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena)(in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Length under 10 mm; mesepisternum and propodeumn, including triangle, strongly rugosely wrinkled
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hyperandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Mandibles long and sickle-shaped, crossed; terga ﬁnely and densely punctate with broad, shining marginal zones
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Length less than 10 mm; mesepisternum shagreened and ﬁnely punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Zonandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Clypeus densely and deeply punctate; metasoma usually strongly punctate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment almost as long as second and third taken together
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Clypeus strongly convex, usually densely but shallowly punctate; metasoma usually ﬁnely and sparsely punctate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually only a little longer than second
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pallandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- First recurrent vein ending in vicinity of base of second submarginal cell; clypeus normally long and distinctly convex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ulandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Penis valve usually strongly bladder-shaped and enlarged; apex of gonostylus usually thickened and broadly shovel-shaped
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poliandrena)(in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Metasoma strongly and usually densely punctate; clypeus short and narrow, ﬂattened
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Avandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Small species; propodeal triangle shagreened, not rugose
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Medium-sized species; propodeal triangle with conspicuous rugae near anterior margin
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melittoides) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Malar area rather long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nobandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Paraocular area in addition to clypeus yellow; scutum ﬁnely shagreened, ﬁnely, shallowly and sparsely punctate; metasoma almost bare
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scaphandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Paraocular area and clypeus dark, rarely with small spot of yellow; scutum usually coarsely shagreened, punctures usually not evident or coarser and indistinct; metasoma usually relatively densely haired
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Parandrenella) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Small species; S8 strongly thickened on outer side, with several dense hair tufts
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Penis valve narrow, ventral lamella broadened laterally; apex of gonostylus narrowly shovel-shaped
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ulandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Penis valve usually strongly bladder-shaped and enlarged; apex of gonostylus usually thickened and broadly shovel-shaped
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Orandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Dorsolateral angle of pronotum distinctly elevated as transverse ridge, with dorsoventral carina extending down from it
- Clypeus somewhat elongated; ﬁrst submarginal crossvein meeting marginal cell only about three to four vein widths away from stigma
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poliandrena)(in part) and A. (T arsandrena)(in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Propodeal triangle rugosely areolate; metasoma usually shiny and strongly punctate; clypeus usually yellow; genitalia complex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Campylogaster) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Mesepisternum strongly and deeply punctate; head thick, with short clypeus; genitalia simple
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Mesepisternum strongly rugose in longitudinal direction, almost undulate-areolate; clypeus and adjacent parts of face yellow; S8 with broad, isolated transverse carina on outer side before apex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Propodeal triangle shagreened, with only a few ﬂat and short rugae near anterior margin; metasoma shagreened and ﬁnely, inconspicuously punctate; clypeus dark; genitalia simple
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poliandrena)(in part) and A. (T arsandrena)(in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Propodeal triangle rugosely areolate; metasoma usually shiny and strongly punctate; clypeus usually yellow; genitalia complex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Mesepisternum strongly rugose in longitudinal direction, almost undulate-areolate; clypeus and adjacent parts of face yellow; S8 with broad, isolated transverse carina on outer side before apex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Carandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Galeal blade of normal length; mesepisternum ﬁnely punctate; propodeal triangle shagreened with few short rugae near anterior margin; metasoma usually very ﬁnely punctate; gonostylar apex and penis valve scarcely broadened
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Galeal blade short; mesepisternum strongly punctate; propodeal triangle shagreened and weakly rugosely areolate; metasoma usually conspicuously punctate; gonostylar apex and penis valve distinctly broadened
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Larandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Clypeus yellow
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Clypeus ﬂattened and broad, anterior margin usually distinctly indented; genitalia complex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Propodeal triangle rugosely wrinkled; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell about in middle; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment longer than second
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key):
- Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines
- Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar
- Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it
- Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny to shagreened, without rugae; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell far beyond middle; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually very short, seldom longer than second
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Parandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells two
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Body length about or less than 7 mm; T1 impunctate or ﬁnely and sparsely punctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Body length about or more than 8 mm; if occasionally smaller, then T1 closely punctate
- Propodeal triangle clearly indicated, coarsely roughened to strongly wrinkled, basal area bounded posteriorly by transverse carina or by strong wrinkles behind which surface is declivous
- Facial fovea separated from eye by wide, shiny space; scutum and scutellum either foveolate-punctate or very strongly rugoso-punctate; inner hind tibial spur neither widened nor curved near base; trochanteral ﬂoccus incomplete, scanty; body length less than 10 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- T riangle of propodeum large, well indicated, sparsely wrinkled; propodeum outside triangle densely tessellate and densely rugose
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Body length about or more than 8 mm; if occasionally smaller, then T1 closely punctate
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured, or, if coarsely sculptured, then apex of triangle not bounded by a transverse carina nor by irregular rugae
- Tibial scopa well developed, composed of long, dense, branched hairs, and femoral scopal hairs also branched
- Head elongate; clypeus protuberant
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Body length about or more than 8 mm; if occasionally smaller, then T1 closely punctate
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured, or, if coarsely sculptured, then apex of triangle not bounded by a transverse carina nor by irregular rugae
- Tibial scopa well developed, composed of long, dense, branched hairs, and femoral scopal hairs also branched
- Head broader than long, more or less round in front view; clypeus not protuberant
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Habromelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Body length about or more than 8 mm; if occasionally smaller, then T1 closely punctate
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured, or, if coarsely sculptured, then apex of triangle not bounded by a transverse carina nor by irregular rugae
- Tibial scopa and femoral scopa largely composed of simple hairs
- Third submarginal cell receiving second recurrent vein at end of cell or close to it
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Body length about or more than 8 mm; if occasionally smaller, then T1 closely punctate
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured, or, if coarsely sculptured, then apex of triangle not bounded by a transverse carina nor by irregular rugae
- Tibial scopa and femoral scopa largely composed of simple hairs
- Third submarginal cell receiving second recurrent vein well before end of cell
- Middle basitarsus strongly expanded medially, subequal to or broader than hind basitarsus (the latter widened subbasally)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Body length about or more than 8 mm; if occasionally smaller, then T1 closely punctate
- Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured, or, if coarsely sculptured, then apex of triangle not bounded by a transverse carina nor by irregular rugae
- Tibial scopa and femoral scopa largely composed of simple hairs
- Third submarginal cell receiving second recurrent vein well before end of cell
- Middle basitarsus slender, not widened medially (or at most only slightly so)
- T1 densely, ﬁnely punctate; T2 and T3 progressively more sparsely, ﬁnely punctate; metasoma sparsely hairy, without distinct hair fringes; posterior margins of metasomal terga yellowish-transparent; clypeus densely tessellate, dull, sparsely and more or less weakly punctate, with broad, median, longitudinal, impunctate space; antenna short, swollen toward apical segments, ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one and one-half times as long as broad, about as long as second plus third segments; scutum tessellate, more or less weakly punctate, covered with rather short, pale fulvous hairs; propodeal triangle well indicated, distinctly wrinkled all over; propodeum outside triangle densely rugulose or nearly shagreened; robust species, length about or less than 8 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Metasoma with integument densely tessellate, therefore dull, impunctate or with indications of weak, sparse punctures; posterior margins of T3 and T4 each with complete, narrow band of short, dense, appressed, white hairs, a similar hair band usually on posterior margin of T2; interior of propodeal corbicula with sparse, usually coarse, simple hairs throughout
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Metasoma tessellate, impunctate, dull or slightly shiny; trochanteral ﬂoccus complete, well developed
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- T riangle of propodeum large, well indicated, sparsely wrinkled; propodeum outside triangle densely tessellate and densely rugose
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Propodeal corbicula with sparse, coarse, simple hairs nearly throughout interior; dorsal fringe of corbicula rather well indicated but not well developed, rather short and not especially dense; no fringe of hairs on anterior margin of corbicula; trochanteral ﬂoccus complete, dense; metasoma smooth and shiny, weakly to very weakly punctate; interocellar distance equal to or a little longer than ocelloccipital distance
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Propodeal corbicula well developed, with dorsal fringe of long, dense, well-arranged, curled hairs, and with complete fringe of hairs anteriorly, interior of corbicula free of hairs medially; hind tibia rather short, dilated apically
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Propodeal corbicula moderately well developed, with dorsal fringe of long, dense, rather wellto well-arranged hairs, interior of corbicula with coarse, simple hairs throughout, no complete fringe of hairs anteriorly, but frequently sparse branched hairs present on dorsal portion of anterior margin; trochanteral ﬂoccus incomplete, scanty to dense; tibial scopa compact, well developed; facial fovea separated from eye by a narrow punctate space; mediumsized to large, robust species
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Propodeal corbicula with sparse, coarse, simple hairs nearly throughout interior; dorsal fringe of corbicula rather well indicated but not well developed, rather short and not especially dense; no fringe of hairs on anterior margin of corbicula; trochanteral ﬂoccus complete, dense; metasoma smooth and shiny, weakly to very weakly punctate; interocellar distance equal to or a little longer than ocelloccipital distance
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Metasoma short-oval, densely tessellate-punctate, nearly dull or weakly shiny, posterior margins of intermediate terga with narrow, appressed, pure-white hair bands, those of T3 and T4 complete; head broad and thin, nearly round in front view; clypeus hardly convex, tessellate, coarsely rugoso-punctate; basal area of labrum short, transverse, apex narrowly bilobed; scutum tessellate, rather densely punctate, covered with short, dull, pale, yellowish-brown hairs; propodeum roughened, triangle poorly deﬁned, rugose basally, granulate apically; trochanteral ﬂoccus nearly complete, white; tibial scopa silver-white, narrowly brownish above basally, composed of rather coarse hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Metasomal terga tessellate, sometimes weakly so, therefore nearly dull or weakly shiny, impunctate or rarely with weak punctures; metasoma more or less hairy, posterior margins of intermediate terga with loose to more or less compact hair fringes; propodeal corbicula poorly developed, with dorsal fringe of loose or more or less well-arranged, rather long hairs, interior with sparse, ﬁne hairs; trochanteral ﬂoccus incomplete, scanty; tibial scopa well developed; dorsal surface of propodeum shagreened to roughened; propodeal triangle ﬁnely to rather ﬁnely sculptured, usually less coarsely sculptured than rest of dorsal surface of propodeum; facial fovea rather narrow, upper end occupying about or less than one-half distance between eye and posterior ocellus; head and thorax with rather abundant, not especially long hairs; rather small species
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Mesopleura coarsely sculptured or at least rugose above, or with distinct punctures; dorsal surface of propodeum coarsely sculptured or at least shagreened; dorsal fringe of propodeal corbicula long, rather well to well arranged; trochanteral ﬂoccus usually complete
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Calomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Facial fovea very broad, with upper end occupying full space between eye and posterior ocellus; propodeal triangle large, with lateral margins convex outward; mesopleura w eakly tessellate with distinct, well-separated punctures; tibial scopa compact, with hairs well arranged, not loose
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oreomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.):
- Submarginal cells three
- Facial fovea much narrower; propodeal triangle large, subtriangular, with sides not convex outward; mesopleura densely tessellate, impunctate or with an indication of weak punctures; tibial scopa large, composed of long, rather loose hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Malar area approximately as long as broad; apical segment of antenna uncinate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Habromelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Malar area linear; apical segment of antenna normal
- Second recurrent vein at end of third submarginal cell, meeting third submarginal crossvein or nearly so
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Propodeal triangle rather strongly wrinkled (metasoma very shiny, feebly tessellate, with an indication of sparse ﬁne punctures; posterior margins of T2-T4 with lateral fringes of sparse white hairs; scutellum nearly smooth and shiny anteriorly; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment much longer than second, second about as long as broad)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Malar area linear; apical segment of antenna normal
- Second recurrent vein much basad of third submarginal crossvein
- Clypeus not strongly convex, largely yellow or ivorywhite
- Length about 6 mm, or occasionally slightly larger; metasomal terga, including T1, ﬁnely and densely punctate; propodeal triangle coarsely sculptured; dorsal surface of propodeum roughened; ﬂagellum beneath yellowish brown; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment approximately one and one-half times as long as broad, second much broader than long, about one-half as long as ﬁrst, third as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oreomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Malar area linear; apical segment of antenna normal
- Second recurrent vein much basad of third submarginal crossvein
- Clypeus not strongly convex, largely yellow or ivorywhite
- Length more than 7 mm; or, if occasionally smaller, then without combination of characters listed above
- Head and thorax with abundant brown to blackish hairs, or at least with admixture of brown hairs
- Clypeus and lateral face marks ivory-white or only slightly yellowish; vertex strongly arched in front view
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Calomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Malar area linear; apical segment of antenna normal
- Second recurrent vein much basad of third submarginal crossvein
- Clypeus not strongly convex, largely yellow or ivorywhite
- Length more than 7 mm; or, if occasionally smaller, then without combination of characters listed above
- Head and thorax with abundant brown to blackish hairs, or at least with admixture of brown hairs
- Clypeus yellow, lateral face marks usually lacking; vertex not arched or only slightly convex in front view
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- First ﬂagellar segment slightly longer than second plus third, these broader than long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Malar area linear; apical segment of antenna normal
- Second recurrent vein much basad of third submarginal crossvein
- Clypeus not strongly convex, largely yellow or ivorywhite
- Length more than 7 mm; or, if occasionally smaller, then without combination of characters listed above
- Head and thorax without admixture of brown hairs, primarily covered with yellowish hairs
- Basal area of labrum rather large, transverse, reﬂexed and deeply emarginate at apex; propodeal triangle rugulose or wrinkled all over; body length about 10 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus black
- First ﬂagellar segment at most as long as broad, about one-half as long as second; third and following segments about twice as long as broad, distinctly convex in front; malar area usually with sharp spine posteriorly in spring form (only)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Mandible slender, curved, with sharp falciform apex; malar area evident, about one-third as long as broad; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment slightly longer than broad, much shorter than elongate second segment (about 3:4.2); face covered with pale yellowish hairs; paraocular area, frons, and gena near eye with black hairs; length about 9 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Mandible slender, curved, with sharp falciform apex; malar area evident, about one-third as long as broad; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment slightly longer than broad, much shorter than elongate second segment (about 3:4.2); face covered with pale yellowish hairs; paraocular area, frons, and gena near eye with black hairs; length about 9 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) (in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Length about 10 mm; lower paraocular area with punctures more obscure than those on clypeus; propodeal triangle with wrinkles irregular
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) (in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Length about 10 mm; lower paraocular area with punctures more obscure than those on clypeus; propodeal triangle with wrinkles irregular
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Length less than 9 mm; lower paraocular area with punctures distinct; propodeal triangle with wrinkles longitudinal
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Length about or less than 7 mm; propodeal triangle large, weakly and rather coarsely sculptured; second submarginal crossvein ending close to stigma
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Basal area of labrum protuberant
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Gena well developed, carinate posteriorly
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- First ﬂagellar segment slightly longer than second plus third, these broader than long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Ocellocciptal distance about or more than twice as long as ocellar width
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Propodeal triangle rather strongly wrinkled (metasoma very shiny, feebly tessellate, with an indication of sparse ﬁne punctures; posterior margins of T2-T4 with lateral fringes of sparse white hairs; scutellum nearly smooth and shiny anteriorly; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment much longer than second, second about as long as broad)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Propodeal triangle large, densely, rather weakly wrinkled all over
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Ocelloccipital distance longer than posterior ocellar diameter; metasomal terga tessellate, with distinct, close punctures
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a):
- Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow
- Ocelloccipital distance at most as long as posterior ocellar diameter; metasomal terga tessellate, impunctate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Erythrandrena) of Megandrena:
- Long hairs of fore tarsus of female curved; gonobase of male absent or completely enclosed in bases of gonocoxites
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megandrena s. str.) of Megandrena:
- Long hairs of fore tarsus of female straight; gonobase of male present, a narrow ring (Fig. 51-7a, b)
=====
Characteristics of the Tribe Calliopsini, of the Panurginae:
- S6 of female with curved (i.e., lateral parts oblique) marginal band of dense hairs (Fig. 59-3d), the band sometimes broken medially, elsewhere S6 with only widely scattered minute hairs; base of S6 of female with two broad membranous lobes (visible only on dissection) occupying space between apodemes (Fig. 59-3d); S5 of female with distal margin convex medially; gonostylus of male absent or reduced to small projection usually not reaching middle of penis valve, the latter enormous and complex (Fig. 59-3a, e, h); anterior tentorial pit in outer subantennal suture (Fig. 59-1) (Western Hemisphere)
=====
