Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Papualictus) of Homalictus (Females)(For males, see comments on the subgenera):
- Hairs of lower distal part of outer surface of hind tibia not differentiated from those on rest of surface, and the hairs not erect; undersurface of tibia not or scarcely concave
- T2 to T4 without bands of tomentum; hair on outer surface of hind tibia simple, sparse, almost bristle-like (New Guinea)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Quasilictus) of Homalictus (Females)(For males, see comments on the subgenera):
- Hairs of lower distal part of outer surface of hind tibia not differentiated from those on rest of surface, and the hairs not erect; undersurface of tibia not or scarcely concave
- T2 to T4 with bands of tomentum, broken medially; hair on outer surface of hind tibia short, minutely plumose, appressed (Australia)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lasioglossum s. str.) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein as strong as ﬁrst (Figs. 661a, 66-6a) [usually rather large and robust, body length 6.8-12.0 mm, usually nonmetallic, although Lasioglossum pavonotum (Cockerell) of the Paciﬁc Coast of USA is strongly green] (holarctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum margined at side by vertical carina that extends upward to summit and then mesad at least partway across upper margin, so that there is a sometimes interrupted carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces; body nearly always nonmetallic (holarctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sphecodogastra) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Scopa sparse, consisting of a row of simple bristles on hind trochanter and lower edge of femur, shorter bristles on upper part of femur, and some long, nearly simple hairs on inner side of tibia (nonmetallic) (nearctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Hemihalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Scopa normal, largely plumose (as in Fig. 8-5b)
- Nonmetallic and with two submarginal cells; inner hind tibial spur of female serrate (nearctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Eickwortia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Scopa normal, largely plumose (as in Fig. 8-5b)
- Nonmetallic or metallic, with three submarginal cells or, in a few metallic species, with two; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with a few large teeth
- Mandible of female strongly bidentate at apex; middorsal length of male gonobase less than one-fourth as long as gonocoxite (Mesoamerica)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Scopa normal, largely plumose (as in Fig. 8-5b)
- Nonmetallic or metallic, with three submarginal cells or, in a few metallic species, with two; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with a few large teeth
- Mandible of female with small, dorsal preapical tooth; middorsal length of male gonobase usually over onethird as long as gonocoxite
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lasioglossum s. str.) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Inner hind tibial spur of female serrate or rarely pectinate with ﬁve or more teeth (holarctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above
- Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces
- T2 of male without basal band of white hairs, or,i f present, then hairs more or less prostrate as on other terga; disc of labrum of female with elevated area or tubercles, not uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate with less than ﬁve long teeth, but sometimes serrate or brieﬂy pectinate with more teeth
- Subpleural signum of female inconspicuous or absent, not elevated as tubercle; inner hind tibial spur of male usually ciliate or minutely dentate
- Posterior surface of propodeum margined at side by vertical carina that extends upward to summit and then mesad at least partway across upper margin, so that there is a sometimes interrupted, transverse carina between basal area and posterior surface, i.e., across posterior margin of basal area; rarely transverse carina present but vertical carina reduced or absent; usually rather large, nonmetallic except for some Asian species (holarctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sphecodogastra) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Scopa sparse, consisting of a row of simple bristles on hind trochanter and lower edge of femur, shorter bristles on upper part of femur, and some long, nearly simple hairs on inner side of tibia (nonmetallic) (nearctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Hemihalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above
- Nonmetallic and with two submarginal cells; inner hind tibial spur of female serrate (nearctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Eickwortia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above
- Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces
- Mandible of female strongly bidentate at apex; middorsal length of male gonobase less than one-fourth as long as gonocoxite (Mesoamerica)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lasioglossum s. str.) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Inner hind tibial spur of female serrate or rarely pectinate with ﬁve or more teeth (holarctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with few large teeth, or with one large tooth followed by undulate margin (Africa, Oriental, Australia)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Acanthalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with two preapical teeth on upper margin; body length 11 to 13 mm; S6 of male ending in thick, shining, uniformly curved and elevated margin (inner hind tibial spur of female serrate) (Siberia)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Paradialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above
- Basitibial plate of female absent (Fig. 66-17d); scopa of female represented by only a few hairs; propodeum with vertical lunate ﬂange separating lateral from posterior surfaces (male unknown) (Africa)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sellalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above
- Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces
- T2 of male with broad, basal band of erect white hairs; disc of labrum of female rather uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female serrate or,i fpectinate, then with ﬁve or more teeth, all longer than broad (Africa)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sudila) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above
- Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces
- T2 of male without basal band of white hairs, or,i f present, then hairs more or less prostrate as on other terga; disc of labrum of female with elevated area or tubercles, not uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate with less than ﬁve long teeth, but sometimes serrate or brieﬂy pectinate with more teeth
- Subpleural signum of female usually elevated as distinct tubercle in front of middle coxa; inner hind tibial spur of male brieﬂy pectinate (Oriental)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above
- Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces
- T2 of male without basal band of white hairs, or,i f present, then hairs more or less prostrate as on other terga; disc of labrum of female with elevated area or tubercles, not uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate with less than ﬁve long teeth, but sometimes serrate or brieﬂy pectinate with more teeth
- Subpleural signum of female inconspicuous or absent, not elevated as tubercle; inner hind tibial spur of male usually ciliate or minutely dentate
- Posterior surface of propodeum margined at side by vertical carina that extends upward to summit and then mesad at least partway across upper margin, so that there is a sometimes interrupted, transverse carina between basal area and posterior surface, i.e., across posterior margin of basal area; rarely transverse carina present but vertical carina reduced or absent; usually rather large, nonmetallic except for some Asian species (holarctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere:
- Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)
- Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green
- Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above
- Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces
- T2 of male without basal band of white hairs, or,i f present, then hairs more or less prostrate as on other terga; disc of labrum of female with elevated area or tubercles, not uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate with less than ﬁve long teeth, but sometimes serrate or brieﬂy pectinate with more teeth
- Subpleural signum of female inconspicuous or absent, not elevated as tubercle; inner hind tibial spur of male usually ciliate or minutely dentate
- Posterior surface of propodeum usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or,i f attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between basal area and posterior surface, i.e., so that basal area is usually not enclosed; body commonly smaller, sometimes metallic
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austrevylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Second submarginal crossvein in both sexes narrower than ﬁrst (as in Fig. 66-6c); small (less than 7 mm long); inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate, essentially simple, or in some cases bearing a few large oblique teeth (body dull, nonmetallic) (Hemihalictus series)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudochilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Second submarginal crossvein as strong as ﬁrst (as in Fig. 66-6a); if body less than 7 mm long, then inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with one to several large teeth, teeth usually not so sloping or oblique as in the above (Lasioglossumseries)
- Females
- Apical labral process triangular (Fig. 66-13a, b), widest at base, tapering to pointed apex, apex usually simple except for being keeled (two keels in a few Parasphecodes, process broadened preapically in a few Ctenonomia) (basitibial plates usually rather elongate and pointed apically)
- Inner hind tibial spur ﬁnely serrate, ciliate, or essentially simple (Fig. 66-13a, b)
- Metasomal terga black with broad basal bands of tomentum; teeth of inner margin of inner hind tibial spur about half as long as diameter of spur
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Parasphecodes) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Propodeal triangle roughened, basal area usually deﬁned; thorax black
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Callalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Propodeal triangle smooth, basal area not margined; thorax partly or wholly red or testaceous
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Second submarginal crossvein as strong as ﬁrst (as in Fig. 66-6a); if body less than 7 mm long, then inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with one to several large teeth, teeth usually not so sloping or oblique as in the above (Lasioglossumseries)
- Females
- Apical labral process triangular (Fig. 66-13a, b), widest at base, tapering to pointed apex, apex usually simple except for being keeled (two keels in a few Parasphecodes, process broadened preapically in a few Ctenonomia) (basitibial plates usually rather elongate and pointed apically)
- Inner hind tibial spur pectinate with a few coarse teeth (coarsely serrate in a few species)
- Propodeum with triangle variously roughened, basal area often margined by a carina; thorax black; metasomal terga usually with tomentum basally or basolaterally
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Glossalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Glossa about two-thirds as long as face, which is broader than long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Chilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Second submarginal crossvein as strong as ﬁrst (as in Fig. 66-6a); if body less than 7 mm long, then inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with one to several large teeth, teeth usually not so sloping or oblique as in the above (Lasioglossumseries)
- Females
- Apical labral process broadened so that it does not taper uniformly to a pointed apex (Fig. 66-13c-f ), lateral margins often pectinate, toothed, elevated, or otherwise modiﬁed
- Inner hind tibial spur of female not pectinate; glossa little more than one-half as long as face; margin of labral process of female variously modiﬁed
- Inner hind tibial spur with a large tooth followed by a wavy margin (Figs. 66-13d, e), tooth in some cases reduced so that margin is almost simple, rarely a second tooth developed sufﬁciently that spur is almost pectinate; eyes usually bare, but in some cases with rather long hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Australictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Gonostylus almost absent or at most short and triangular
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Glossalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Glossa about two-thirds as long as face, which is broader than long
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) (in part) —. Gonostylus more than half as long as gonocoxite (except in L. idoneum Cockerell), in some cases as long as gono- coxite ........................................................L. (Chilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Glossa longer than face, which is longer than broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Australictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Gonostylus almost absent or at most short and triangular
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Callalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Propodeal triangle smooth, basal area not margined; thorax partly or wholly red or testaceous
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Parasphecodes) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region:
- Propodeal triangle roughened, basal area usually deﬁned; thorax black
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Lomatalictus) of Patellapis:
- Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)
- Metasomal terga with apical hair bands, without basal bands or lateral areas of tomentum; claws of female simple or with inner tooth very small, those of male with teeth close together (S4 of male unmodiﬁed) (Africa)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Zonalictus) of Patellapis:
- Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)
- Metasomal terga without strong apical hair bands, frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum; claws of both sexes toothed, as usual in halictines
- Posterior margins of terga, especially T1 to T3, bare, nearly always contrastingly white, yellow, greenish, or bluish (Africa, Arabia)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Archihalictus) of Patellapis:
- Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)
- Metasomal terga without strong apical hair bands, frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum; claws of both sexes toothed, as usual in halictines
- Posterior margins of terga brownish or translucent, commonly with weak or very weak apical hair bands
- Scutum and scutellum smooth or minutely roughened to coarsely striate, with punctures well separated at least in some areas; metasomal terga without areas of pale tomentum (ignoring pale hairs arising from graduli); S4 of male similar in size and shape to S3 and S5, without very large bristles (Madagascar)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachyhalictus) of Patellapis:
- Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)
- Metasomal terga without strong apical hair bands, frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum; claws of both sexes toothed, as usual in halictines
- Posterior margins of terga brownish or translucent, commonly with weak or very weak apical hair bands
- Scutum and scutellum coarsely and closely punctate or punctures usually so large that surface is coarsely reticulate, rarely, as in Pachyhalictus (Pachyhalictus) binghami (Kirby), with partly smooth areas; metasomal terga (at least T2 and T3) with basal areas of pale tomentum, sometimes expanded to cover whole terga; S4 of male short, largely hidden, with a few large apical or preapical bristles
- Inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with three to six long teeth; basitibial plate of male absent or indicated only at apex; S4 of male not produced posteriorly at side but with an enormous and complex lateral bristle, usually hidden by T4 (Fig. 66-20c); ﬁrst two hind tarsal segments of male fused (Oriental to Australia)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dictyohalictus) of Patellapis:
- Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)
- Metasomal terga without strong apical hair bands, frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum; claws of both sexes toothed, as usual in halictines
- Posterior margins of terga brownish or translucent, commonly with weak or very weak apical hair bands
- Scutum and scutellum coarsely and closely punctate or punctures usually so large that surface is coarsely reticulate, rarely, as in Pachyhalictus (Pachyhalictus) binghami (Kirby), with partly smooth areas; metasomal terga (at least T2 and T3) with basal areas of pale tomentum, sometimes expanded to cover whole terga; S4 of male short, largely hidden, with a few large apical or preapical bristles
- Inner hind tibial spur of female serrate or pectinate with ten or more teeth; basitibial plate of male present; S4 of male produced posteriorly at side with several large bristles usually hidden by T4; ﬁrst two hind tarsal segments of male apparently articulated, but articulation broader than that between subsequent tarsomeres (Africa)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Patellapis s. str.) of Patellapis:
- Posterior tibia of female with long hairs of lower margin strongly curved posteriorly toward apex of tibia, or distal parts usually curved upward across outer surface of tibia, with well-separated long branches directed in same general direction as rachis, or usually branched in such a way that the rachis is not identiﬁable except basally; distal parts of long marginal hairs overlapping hairs of outer tibial surface, and intermediate hair types seemingly present, thus there is no striking superﬁcial contrast between long hairs of lower margin and hairs of outer surface (this is as in Lasioglossumand Halictus); metasomal terga without basal bands or lateral areas of tomentum, frequently with apical bands of pale hairs
- T erga with conspicuous apical hair bands; basitibial plate margined both in front and behind, its apex in female usually rounded (Africa)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Chaetalictus) of Patellapis:
- Posterior tibia of female with long hairs of lower margin strongly curved posteriorly toward apex of tibia, or distal parts usually curved upward across outer surface of tibia, with well-separated long branches directed in same general direction as rachis, or usually branched in such a way that the rachis is not identiﬁable except basally; distal parts of long marginal hairs overlapping hairs of outer tibial surface, and intermediate hair types seemingly present, thus there is no striking superﬁcial contrast between long hairs of lower margin and hairs of outer surface (this is as in Lasioglossumand Halictus); metasomal terga without basal bands or lateral areas of tomentum, frequently with apical bands of pale hairs
- T erga without or with weak apical hair bands; basitibial plate not or incompletely deﬁned on anterior margin, its apex in female angulate or pointed (Africa)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Brasilagapostemon) of Pseudagapostemon:
- Eyes conspicuously hairy; malar area of male about onethird as long as second ﬂagellar segment (Brazil)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Neagapostemon) of Pseudagapostemon:
- Eyes nearly bare; malar area of male usually one-ﬁfth as long as second ﬂagellar segment or less
- Clypeus usually with longitudinal median elevation or carina, and, in males, ﬁne striae lacking or not converging on midline
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pseudagapostemon s. str.) of Pseudagapostemon:
- Eyes nearly bare; malar area of male usually one-ﬁfth as long as second ﬂagellar segment or less
- Clypeus without longitudinal median ridge or carina except sometimes at uppermost end of clypeus, and, in males, with ﬁne oblique striae converging downward to midline of clypeus
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Eothrincostoma) of Thrinchostoma(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1978a):
- Forewing without an area of dense hairs along second submarginal crossvein, this vein simple and straight; ﬁrst submarginal crossvein arising far from base of vein r and margin of stigma; S4 of male with a series of enormous simple bristles arising from margin both medially under S3 and laterally, under the lateral extremity of T4, where the setae are largest (Africa)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Diagonozus) of Thrinchostoma(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1978a):
- Forewing with an area of dense hairs near median part of second submarginal crossvein, these hairs forming, in males, a conspicuous dark spot, this crossvein usually angulate or thickened medially, sometimes incomplete (not reaching marginal cell); ﬁrst submarginal crossvein arising very near margin of stigma; S4 of male without coarse, specialized setae
- Head extraordinarily produced below eyes, malar area nearly as long as or longer than eye, several times as long as wide (Fig 66-22b)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Thrinchostoma s. str.) of Thrinchostoma(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1978a):
- Forewing with an area of dense hairs near median part of second submarginal crossvein, these hairs forming, in males, a conspicuous dark spot, this crossvein usually angulate or thickened medially, sometimes incomplete (not reaching marginal cell); ﬁrst submarginal crossvein arising very near margin of stigma; S4 of male without coarse, specialized setae
- Head only moderately produced below eyes, malar area much shorter than eye, three times as long as wide or less
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Ariphanarthra of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Maxillary palpus much longer than stipes plus galea, reaching metasoma when mouthparts are in repose (basitibial plate moderately developed, much exceeding apex of femur, as in Fig. 67-5c)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptidia of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened
- Eye greatly enlarged, projecting above vertex (Fig. 677b), separated from lateral ocellus and from vertical part of epistomal suture above tentorial pit by one-fourth of ocellar diameter or less (basitibial plate not short, much surpassing apex of femur; ocelli much enlarged)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened
- Eyes not projecting above vertex, widely separated from lateral ocellus and from epistomal suture above tentorial pit (Fig. 67-6, 67-13g)
- Pronotal dorsal surface swollen, dorsolateral angle and vertical ridge below angle absent; paraocular lobe long, lower end acute (Fig. 67-13a, b); head elongated, owing to greatly lengthened clypeus; inner hind tibial spur serrate
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Megommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened
- Eyes not projecting above vertex, widely separated from lateral ocellus and from epistomal suture above tentorial pit (Fig. 67-6, 67-13g)
- Pronotal dorsal surface normal, not swollen; paraocular lobe approximately right-angular (Fig. 67-7a); head not greatly elongated; inner hind tibial spur pectinate or serrate
- Basitibial plate very short, scarcely surpassing apex of femur
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Micrommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened
- Eyes not projecting above vertex, widely separated from lateral ocellus and from epistomal suture above tentorial pit (Fig. 67-6, 67-13g)
- Pronotal dorsal surface normal, not swollen; paraocular lobe approximately right-angular (Fig. 67-7a); head not greatly elongated; inner hind tibial spur pectinate or serrate
- Basitibial plate moderately developed (ocelli small; inner hind tibial spur serrate) (placed here on the basis of the description; I have seen no specimens)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera T emnosoma of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis not so slender (Fig. 67-4a, c-e), prementum four to eight times as long as broad; proboscidial fossa much wider than mandibular base
- Inner hind tibial spur serrate, teeth shorter than wide, pointed or rounded, or margin of spur undulate or ciliate (Fig. 67-5f, g, k-m)
- Scopa and median specialized area of T5 absent; integument coarsely punctate (Fig. 67-15); labral process truncate, without keel (Fig. 65-1i)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Epistomal suture forming acute paraocular lobe protruding into clypeus (Fig. 67-6d); clypeus relatively ﬂat, green almost to apex; anterior angle of hypostomal carina usually a sharp right angle or produced into spine; apex of marginal cell narrowly truncate and usually appendiculate (Fig. 67-1a)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorella of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Epistomal suture forming obtuse or right angle laterally (Fig. 67-6c); clypeus beveled, area below angle not green; anterior angle of hypostomal carina rounded; apex of marginal cell acute or very narrowly truncate
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Corynura (Corynura) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Basal area of propodeum completely smooth or granular, without striae; eyes deeply emarginate (Fig. 67-6a) (preoccipital ridge gradually rounded)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Paroxystoglossa —. Preoccipital ridge rounded; mesoscutum very slightly narrowed anteriorly, lip low and rounded; labral basal el- evation transverse ..........................................Megaloptilla of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Preoccipital ridge sharply angled; mesoscutum strongly narrowed anteriorly, lip high and sharply angled; labral basal elevation suborbiculate
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Caenaugochlora (Ctenaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Preoccipital carina strong, even almost lamella-like; apex of marginal cell minutely truncate; basal area of propodeum about as long as scutellum
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogella (Ischnomelissa) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Preoccipital ridge rounded; apex of marginal cell pointed; basal area of propodeum about as long as scutellum and metanotum taken together (head at least as long as broad)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogella (Chlerogella) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Pronotum convex dorsally, dorsolateral angle and vertical ridge below angle absent; paraocular lobe acute (Fig. 67-7e); scutellum normal; ﬂagellum ten-segmented
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogas of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Pronotum normal in form; paraocular lobe right-angular (Fig. 67-7f, g); scutellum produced into two convexities; ﬂagellum nine-segmented
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Megalopta of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Eyes and ocelli enlarged, ocellocular distance thus equal to or less than ocellar diameter (Fig. 67-7d, 6713d); hamuli in a closely packed series (Fig. 67-1b); hind tibia covered with amber setae
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Xenochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Eyes and ocelli not enlarged, ocellocular distance twice ocellar diameter or more; hamuli in series broken by gaps (as in most other Augochlorini), some hooks thus isolated; hind tibia and basitarsus largely covered with black setae
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochloropsis of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- T egula with inner posterior angle produced mesally, forming an emargination in the posterior part of the mesal tegular margin (Fig. 67-5t); basitibial plate very short, poorly deﬁned, extending barely past apex of femur (Fig. 67-8a); labrum with distal process expanded and rounded, as broad as body of labrum (Fig. 65-1g), distal keel projecting beyond apex (pronotal dorsal ridge between lateral angle and pronotal lobe lamellate, forming ﬂange from lateral angle to lobe)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Rhinocorynura of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Vertex swollen behind ocelli; clypeus usually armed with spines or median tubercle (Fig. 67-7h); basal area of propodeum smooth, usually depressed transversely; base of T1 normal
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Thectochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Vertex not swollen; clypeus not armed; basal area of propodeum short, striate, completely covered with short, dense pile; T1 with basal enclosure formed by dense plumose hairs near petiole, usually containing large mites
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Rhectomia of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Pronotal dorsolateral angle produced, strongly carinate anteriorly and laterally behind angle, dorsal ridge not carinate behind dorsolateral angle, but vertical ridge below angle carinate (mesoscutum slightly produced over pronotum, low and sharply angled; preoccipital ridge rounded)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Andinaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Basitibial plate well-deﬁned posteriorly, obsolescent anteriorly (Fig. 67-5q); pronotal dorsolateral angle not produced, obtuse; eye hairs short
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Neocorynura of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Preoccipital ridge carinate or lamellate; mesoscutum usually narrowed anteriorly and anterior mesoscutal lip usually narrow, high, projecting forward and sharply angled; pronotal dorsolateral angle usually strongly produced, lateral ridge carinate or lamellate; propodeum usuallynarrowed posteriorly
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Corynura (Callistochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Eyes with long hair; basitibial plate deﬁned only posteriorly, very short (Fig. 67-5p)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorodes of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Pronotal dorsal ridge strongly carinate; marginal cell with apex acute; body length approximately 7 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Pseudaugochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Vertex produced to rounded ridge behind ocelli (Fig. 67-14a); preoccipital ridge rounded; galea of maxilla with apex pointed, well sclerotized; basal elevation of labrum with apical surface ﬂattened, rimmed (Fig. 651b)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Caenaugochlora (Caenaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Vertex not produced; preoccipital ridge usually sharply angled or carinate; galea normal, with apical lobe; basal elevation of labrum without ﬂattened distal surface
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Ariphanarthra of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Maxillary palpus much longer than stipes plus galea, reaching metasoma when mouthparts are in repose
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptidia of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened
- Eyes greatly enlarged, projecting above vertex, separated from lateral ocellus and from vertical part of epistomal suture above tentorial pit by one-fourth of ocellar diameter or less (Fig. 67-7b); S4 bilobed with deep median notch, the lobes strongly pilose (ocelli much enlarged)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened
- Eyes not projecting above vertex, widely separated from lateral ocellus and epistomal suture above tentorial pit (Fig. 67-6); S4 not bilobed
- Pronotal dorsal surface swollen; paraocular lobe long, acute; head elongate owing to greatly lengthened clypeus; middle femur sometimes greatly swollen and ﬂattened
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogella (in part) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Pronotum convex dorsally, lateral angle a mere convexity and vertical ridge below angle absent; epistomal suture forming acute paraocular lobe laterally; scutellum normal; ﬂagellum 11-segmented
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogas of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Pronotum normal; epistomal suture forming right angle laterally (Fig. 67-7f, g); scutellum produced into two large tubercles; ﬂagellum 10-segmented
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochloropsis of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- T egula with inner posterior angle produced mesally (Fig. 67-5t); posterior margins of T1 and T2 frequently each with a row of strong simple setae (pronotal dorsal ridge lamellate, forming ﬂange from lateral angle to lobe; S4 usually with posterolateral appendage (Fig. 67-9c, f, but see also b), the appendage usually hidden or partly projecting from beneath T4; S4 posteriorly emarginate with median point; marginal cell truncate)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Megalopta of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Eyes and ocelli enlarged, ocellocular distance usually less than ocellar diameter (Fig. 67-7d); S3 bilobed; S4 with posterior margin notched laterally, bilobed medially, and with median ﬂap; pronotal dorsal ridge rounded and narrow, anterior edge of dorsolateral angle and vertical ridge below dorsolateral angle both carinate
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Thectochlora (in part) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Vertex not swollen; basal area of propodeum striate; S4 produced into caudally directed lateral process bearing strong setae (usually hidden), posterior margin medially depressed and truncate, disc of S4 with a median patch of short, erect, stout setae; S5 emarginate, with long plumose pubescence; scape less than 1.5 times as long as second ﬂagellar segment
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Paroxystoglossa of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- S4 and S5 depressed medially and shiny, posterior margin of S4 broadly emarginate (as in Fig. 67-9a); venter of head and mesosoma and lower surfaces of legs clothed with long plumose pubescence; metasoma not petiolate
=====
Characteristics to the Genera T emnosoma of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Body very coarsely punctate; T1 to T3 strongly depressed basally (Fig. 67-15); T7 prolonged apically and bilobed
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Rhinocorynura of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Vertex swollen above ocelli; basal area of propodeum smooth; S4 and S5 unmodiﬁed; scape more than twice length of second ﬂagellar segment
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Thectochlora (in part) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Vertex not swollen; basal area of propodeum striate; S4 produced into caudally directed lateral process bearing strong setae (usually hidden), posterior margin medially depressed and truncate, disc of S4 with a median patch of short, erect, stout setae; S5 emarginate, with long plumose pubescence; scape less than 1.5 times as long as second ﬂagellar segment
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogella (Ischnomelissa) (in part) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Basal area of propodeum about as long as scutellum and metanotum combined; propodeal pit narrow, not enclosed by V-shaped depression; paraocular lobe about right-angular; pronotal dorsal ridge not carinate; gonostylus not divided into dorsal and ventral gonostylar processes
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Halictillus of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Metasoma elongate, not petiolate, dull metallic blue-green; body about 5 to 6 mm long; bridge of penis valves shifted apicad to level of apices of gonocoxites
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Corynura of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Metasoma petiolate, ﬁrst two segments long and narrow, or, if not, then body usually bright green or orangegreen; body length usually over 6 mm; bridge of penis valves in usual position near level of middles of gonocoxites
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptilla of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Mesoscutum weakly narrowed anteriorly; dorsal pronotal ridge between lateral angle and lobe carinate, vertical ridge below angle not carinate; apical margin of S5 unmodiﬁed
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Rhectomia of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Mesoscutum broadly rounded anteriorly; dorsal pronotal ridge between lateral angle and lobe not carinate, vertical ridge below angle carinate; apical margin of S5 with weak median notch
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorodes of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Basal area of propodeum smooth; S5 with dense clump of setae medially; S6 shallowly notched along apical margin; dorsal lobes of gonobase weakly deﬁned; venter of penis valve without prong
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Neocorynurella) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Basal area of propodeum striate; S5 with scattered setae; S6 deeply notched along apical margin; dorsal lobes of gonobase strong; penis valve with ventral prong
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorella (Ceratalictus) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Antenna reaching about to scutellum, scape more than 2.5 times length of second ﬂagellar segment, which is subequal to ﬁrst; scutum not narrowed and not produced over pronotum (integument bright green; tibiae and tarsi orange)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Paroxystoglossa of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- S4 and S5 depressed medially and shiny, posterior margin of S4 broadly emarginate (as in Fig. 67-9a); venter of head and mesosoma and lower surfaces of legs clothed with long plumose pubescence; metasoma not petiolate
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Neocorynura of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- S4 and S5 not modiﬁed; ventral surfaces without long plumose pubescence; metasoma frequently petiolate, S1 and S2 usually very long and narrow (compare with Andinaugochlora)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Andinaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Antenna very long, surpassing propodeum; scape twice length of second ﬂagellar segment or less; ﬂagellum with plate areas containing only sensory plate-organs, these areas without setae; S6 strongly notched with deep concavities on either side of median notch
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Epistomal suture forming acute lateral angle or paraocular lobe protruding into clypeus (Fig. 67-6d); marginal cell truncate, usually appendiculate (Fig. 671a)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorella of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Epistomal suture forming right angle laterally (Fig. 676c); marginal cell acute, rarely very narrowly truncate
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Pseudaugochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Apical ﬂagellar segment tapering, hooked (Fig. 6714c); preoccipital ridge rounded
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Caenaugochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.):
- Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base
- Apical ﬂagellar segment rounded; preoccipital ridge sharply angled or carinate
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andinaugochlora s. str.) of Andinaugochlora:
- Preoccipital carina present although weak behind vertex; anterior margin of basitibial plate of female absent; paraocular lobe near right-angular (about 100 /H11034); penis valve without ventral prong
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Neocorynurella) of Andinaugochlora:
- Preoccipital carina absent; anterior margin of basitibial plate of female a distinct carina; paraocular lobe strongly obtuse (about 135/H11034); penis valve with ventral prong
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oxystoglossella) of Augochlora:
- Female: Mandible normal, preapical tooth not produced, far from apex of mandible; median area of T5 with long setae, not scale-like; S1 usually normal, rarely with slight median ridge or tooth; basitibial plate usually narrowly rounded, occasionally broadly rounded; basal elevation of labrum suborbicular. Male: Ventral gonostylus with long setae, greatly surpassing gonostylus
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochlora s. str.) of Augochlora:
- Female: Mandible bidentate, preapical tooth and occasionally outer ridge produced; median area of T5 with scale-like setae; S1 frequently with tooth or median ridge, sometimes unarmed; basitibial plate broadly rounded (Fig. 67-8b); basal elevation of labrum transverse. Male: Ventral gonostylus with short setae (Fig. 67-10d)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ceratalictus) of Augochlorella (Females):
- Epistomal suture forming obtuse paraocular lobe (as in Fig. 67-6b); inner hind tibial spur broadest near middle (Fig. 67-5l); basitibial plate poorly deﬁned on anterior edge (preoccipital ridge carinate)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pereirapis) of Augochlorella (Females):
- Epistomal suture forming right-angular or slightly obtuse paraocular lobe (Fig. 67-6c); inner hind tibial spur broadest at basal one-third to one-ﬁfth; basitibial plate well deﬁned on all edges
- Inner hind tibial spur with few short, rounded teeth, basal tooth largest, forming broadest part of spur (Fig. 67-5m); basal area of propodeum strongly granular, striate basally; body length about 5 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochlorella s. str.) of Augochlorella (Females):
- Epistomal suture forming right-angular or slightly obtuse paraocular lobe (Fig. 67-6c); inner hind tibial spur broadest at basal one-third to one-ﬁfth; basitibial plate well deﬁned on all edges
- Inner hind tibial spur with rounded serrations, basal part broadened and serrate, i.e., not formed from a single tooth; basal area of propodeum not strongly granular; body length usually over 5 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ceratalictus) of Augochlorella (Males):
- Epistomal suture forming obtuse paraocular lobe; dorsal gonostylus with long, narrow, hairless basal process extending mesad to midline
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pereirapis) of Augochlorella (Males):
- Epistomal suture forming right-angular paraocular lobe; dorsal gonostylus without such a mesal process
- S4 broadly emarginate posteriorly, laterally bearing long, modiﬁed setae that are usually hidden; body length about 5 mm; inner lobe of ventral gonostylus without row of coarse setae
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochlorella s. str.) of Augochlorella (Males):
- Epistomal suture forming right-angular paraocular lobe; dorsal gonostylus without such a mesal process
- S4 not broadly emarginate, without long lateral setae; body length usually over 5 mm; inner lobe of ventral gonostylus bearing marginal row of coarse, ﬂattened setae (Fig. 67-10f)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochloropsis s. str.) of Augochloropsis:
- Basal area of propodeum deeply and regularly pitted or strongly striate basally, smooth apically; S5 of male with apical margin notched, and with long, curved setae centrally; S6 of male with wide apical ﬂange (broken medially) projecting beyond posterior border; distal process of male labrum truncate or notched apically; ventral gonostylus of male bearing row of strong, ﬂattened, modiﬁed setae at apex
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Paraugochloropsis) of Augochloropsis:
- Basal area of propodeum smooth, irregularly roughened, or with light plicae; S5 of male with apical margin entire, setae not modiﬁed; S6 of male with apical ﬂange little developed; distal process of male labrum rounded; ventral gonostylus of male bearing dense unmodiﬁed setae at apex (Fig. 67-12b)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Caenaugochlora s. str.) of Caenaugochlora:
- Basitibial plate of female well deﬁned on all edges; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with well separated teeth (as in Fig. 67-5i); eye hair frequently long; S4 of male bearing distinctive setal clumps on raised tubercles on either side of apical median depression (Fig. 67-9d)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ctenaugochlora) of Caenaugochlora:
- Basitibial plate of female obsolescent anteriorly; inner hind tibial spur of female closely pectinate, with over ten teeth (Fig. 67-5n); eye hair short; S4 of male with Vshaped patch of setae bordering slight median depression
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ischnomelissa) of Chlerogella:
- Inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with over ten close teeth (as in Fig. 67-5n); paraocular lobe slightly acute; male gonostylus undivided
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chlerogella s. str.) of Chlerogella:
- Inner hind tibial spur of female with fewer, well-separated teeth (as in Fig. 67-5i); paraocular lobe strongly acute; male gonostylus divided into dorsal and ventral processes
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ischnomelissa) of Chlerogella:
- Inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with over ten close teeth (as in Fig. 67-5n); paraocular lobe slightly acute; male gonostylus undivided
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megalopta s. str.) of Megalopta:
- Female with scopa and poorly developed basitibial plate (Fig. 67-5s); mandible of female stout, bidentate, with supplementary teeth on inner surface (Fig. 67-5o); S5 of male narrowly emarginate; clypeus and scape of male partly white
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Noctoraptor) of Megalopta:
- Female without either scopa or basitibial plate (Fig. 6713e); mandible of female simple, long and slender, without supplementary teeth (Fig. 67-13d); S5 of male broadly notched; clypeus and scape of male black
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megommation s. str.) of Megommation:
- Ocelli much enlarged, ocellocular distance equal to or less than ocellar diameter (Fig. 67-7a); body length 12 mm or more (inner hind tibial spur of female serrate)
=====
Characteristics of the Subfamily Meganomiinae, of the Melittidae:
- Yellow or cream markings on head, thorax, and metasoma; body length over 10 mm; mandible of female simple; apex of marginal cell rounded, bent away from wing margin (Africa, Arabia)
=====
Characteristics of the Subfamily Dasypodainae, of the Melittidae:
- Yellow or cream markings, if present, limited to male face and rarely areas on legs [except for Eremaphanta (Central Asia; length 6.5 mm or less) which often has abundant yellow markings, and Macropis hedini Popov, which has yellow on supraclypeal area of female]; mandible of female with preapical tooth on upper margin, sometimes two teeth; apex of marginal cell pointed, on or very near wing margin (Fig. 68-1)
- Paraglossa largely bare, usually markedly shorter than suspensorium, its hairs largely limited to apex, or paraglossa absent (Fig. 72-1b); forewing with two submarginal cells, second usually shorter than ﬁrst; ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (/H11005base of second submarginal cell) usually more or less at right angles to longitudinal veins (Fig. 68-1c, d) and usually close to ﬁrst recurrent vein; known larvae do not spin cocoons
=====
Characteristics of the Subfamily Melittinae, of the Melittidae:
- Yellow or cream markings, if present, limited to male face and rarely areas on legs [except for Eremaphanta (Central Asia; length 6.5 mm or less) which often has abundant yellow markings, and Macropis hedini Popov, which has yellow on supraclypeal area of female]; mandible of female with preapical tooth on upper margin, sometimes two teeth; apex of marginal cell pointed, on or very near wing margin (Fig. 68-1)
- Paraglossa densely hairy; forewing with two or three submarginal cells, second (if only two) or second plus third as long as or longer than ﬁrst; ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (/H11005base of second submarginal cell) slanting (Fig. 68-1a, b), usually well separated from ﬁrst recurrent vein; larvae spin cocoons
=====
Characteristics of the Tribe Dasypodaini, of the Dasypodainae:
- Vertex, as seen from front (except in Eremaphanta s. str.), elevated well above summits of eyes, usually convex; gonostylus of male (except in Dasypoda) robust, fused to gonocoxite; S7 of male without or (in some Dasypoda) with only one pair of straplike lateroapical lobes (Fig. 701f); paraglossa small, slender, more or less cylindrical
=====
Characteristics of the Tribe Promelittini, of the Dasypodainae:
- Vertex, as seen from front, little elevated above summits of eyes, gently convex to concave; gonostylus of male long, ﬂexibly joined or articulated to gonocoxite; S7 of male with one or two pairs of broad lateroapical lobes (Fig 72-1f, g); paraglossa tapering distally or absent
- Clypeus of male largely yellow; metasomal terga with basal zones of pale hair; paraglossa nearly as long as its suspensorium; vertex weakly, uniformly convex, as seen from front (Egypt)
=====
Characteristics of the Tribe Sambini, of the Dasypodainae:
- Vertex, as seen from front, little elevated above summits of eyes, gently convex to concave; gonostylus of male long, ﬂexibly joined or articulated to gonocoxite; S7 of male with one or two pairs of broad lateroapical lobes (Fig 72-1f, g); paraglossa tapering distally or absent
- Clypeus of male concolorous with rest of head; metasomal terga usually without basal hair bands, but if bands present, then apical; paraglossa much shorter than its suspensorium or usually not recognizable (Fig. 72-1b); vertex straight or concave, as seen from front (Africa)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Eremaphanta of the Dasypodaini:
- Yellow integumental markings present, at least on face and legs; stigma large, slightly shorter to slightly longer than costal margin of marginal cell; prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female absent (Central Asia)
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Dasypoda of the Dasypodaini:
- Yellow integumental markings absent (except rarely on part of clypeus of male); stigma not enlarged, about half as long as costal margin of marginal cell (Fig. 68-1c, d); prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female well developed, or the former represented by a mere hair band similar to that of T4
- Basitibial plate absent in both sexes; proﬁle of propodeum all more or less in one plane; galeal comb absent or nearly so; male gonostylus well differentiated, nearly always deeply biﬁd (Fig. 70-1d) (palearctic)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Eremaphanta s. str.) ofEremaphanta:
- T erga without apical hair bands; head broader than long; vertex gently convex, scarcely above level of summits of eyes
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Popovapis) ofEremaphanta:
- T erga with apical hair bands; head longer than broad; vertex extending far above summits of eyes
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Capicoloides) of Hesperapis:
- Pygidial plate of female with longitudinal median elevated area, or at least ridges representing edges of such an area; male gonostylus without inner lobe (Fig. 70-1a) (southern Africa)
- Outer surface of hind tibia of female with large, blunt, spinelike hairs among scopal hairs; S7 of male with disc narrowed, with diverging, densely hairy, lateroapical lobes
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Capicola) of Hesperapis:
- Pygidial plate of female with longitudinal median elevated area, or at least ridges representing edges of such an area; male gonostylus without inner lobe (Fig. 70-1a) (southern Africa)
- Outer surface of hind tibia of female without spinelike hairs interspersed among scopal hairs; S7 of male with disc broad, without diverging lateroapical lobes (Fig. 701c)
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Xeralictoides) of Hesperapis:
- Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)
- Mesoscutum as long as or longer than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia with series of ﬁve or more robust, amber apical and posteroapical spines on outer surface
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Panurgomia) of Hesperapis:
- Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)
- Mesoscutum considerably shorter than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia without such spines
- Propodeal triangle contiguously punctured throughout and dull, in contrast to sparsely punctured and shining posterior and lateral propodeal surfaces; pygidial plate of female more or less ﬂat, with mesal area bearing patch of appressed plumose hairs
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) of Hesperapis:
- Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)
- Mesoscutum considerably shorter than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia without such spines
- Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny, at most anteriorly rugose or irregularly punctured, or, if dull and closely punctured, then posterior and lateral propodeal surfaces similar; pygidial plate of female often strongly convex with elevated basal triangle, always without mesal hair patch
- Females
- Hairs along upper (i.e., posterior) margin of hind basitarsus parted, margin being narrowly hairless and exposed
- Pygidial plate with elevated, triangular basal area margined by carinae that meet posteromedially [except in H. oliviae (Cockerell), which lacks these carinae]; body length 7-16 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Hesperapis:
- Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)
- Mesoscutum considerably shorter than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia without such spines
- Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny, at most anteriorly rugose or irregularly punctured, or, if dull and closely punctured, then posterior and lateral propodeal surfaces similar; pygidial plate of female often strongly convex with elevated basal triangle, always without mesal hair patch
- Females
- Hairs along upper (i.e., posterior) margin of hind basitarsus parted, margin being narrowly hairless and exposed
- Pygidial plate ﬂat with shallow longitudinal sulcus near apex, without elevated area; body length 4-7 mm
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Zacesta) of Hesperapis:
- Labial palpus with second segment much longer than ﬁrst; head about as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) —. First ﬂagellar segment equal to or shorter than second ................................................................ H. (Amblyapis) of Hesperapis:
- Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)
- Mesoscutum considerably shorter than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia without such spines
- Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny, at most anteriorly rugose or irregularly punctured, or, if dull and closely punctured, then posterior and lateral propodeal surfaces similar; pygidial plate of female often strongly convex with elevated basal triangle, always without mesal hair patch
- Females
- Hairs along upper (i.e., posterior) margin of hind basitarsus not parted, arising on, as well as on both sides of, the margin
- Head length much less than width; labial palpus with second segment little if any longer than ﬁrst
- First ﬂagellar segment at least 1.6 times length of second
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Zacesta) of Hesperapis:
- Labial palpus with second segment much longer than ﬁrst; head about as long as broad
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.:
- Body length 6 mm or less and metasomal terga with distinct, white, apical hair bands
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.:
- Body length greater than 6 mm or metasomal terga without white apical hair bands, sometimes with pale brown hair bands
- Pygidial plate absent, T7 covered with pubescence 3 3(2). Posterior lobe of pronotum produced into stout, weakly recurved spine; galea dark, sparsely punctured, glabrous
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.:
- Body length greater than 6 mm or metasomal terga without white apical hair bands, sometimes with pale brown hair bands
- Pygidial plate absent, T7 covered with pubescence 3 3(2). Posterior lobe of pronotum produced into stout, weakly recurved spine; galea dark, sparsely punctured, glabrous
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.:
- S6 with apical lobes rounded, shiny and relatively free of hair except for apically directed marginal fringe; terga always with distinct pale apical hair bands
=====
Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Amblyapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.:
- S6 with apical lobes acute, dull, and bearing inner, subapical brush of suberect hair; terga with pale apical hair bands occasionally very weakly developed or absent
- T erga dull with irregular-sized continuous punctures
=====
Characteristics to the Genera Samba of the Sambini:
